intro: Fimbristylis parvilenta, commonly known as the small-bracted sedge, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia and Australia. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with triangular stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, three-lobed flowers, typically arranged in dense clusters. Fimbristylis parvilenta thrives in moist, well-drained soils, often found in wetlands, marshes, or along the edges of water bodies. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, supporting a variety of wildlife.
